questions.statement: Computer ethics is a set of acceptable behaviors for using a computer and the Internet.
questions.explanation: This is the definition of computer ethics as stated in the textbook.

questions.statement: The Internet can only be used for entertainment purposes.
questions.explanation: The Internet has many advantages including education, communication, e-commerce, abundant information, and entertainment.

questions.statement: Google Chrome is a search engine.
questions.explanation: Google Chrome is a web browser, not a search engine. Google is a search engine.

questions.statement: Social media platforms are used for interaction, content sharing, and collaboration.
questions.explanation: Social media refers to the online communication platform used for interaction, content sharing, and collaboration among users.

questions.statement: E-commerce means buying and selling of goods and services online.
questions.explanation: E-commerce enables buying and selling of goods and services online using the Internet.

questions.statement: Spam is a helpful email that provides useful information.
questions.explanation: Spam refers to unwanted, unsolicited, and useless e-mail that may carry advertisements or malware.

questions.statement: Internet addiction can negatively affect students' studies.
questions.explanation: Students who spend a lot of time on social media may waste useful time, which can negatively affect their studies.

questions.statement: Plagiarism is a serious offence that results in severe penalties.
questions.explanation: Plagiarism refers to using others' ideas without acknowledgment and is a serious offence with severe penalties.

questions.statement: Citation is the simplest technique to avoid plagiarism.
questions.explanation: Mentioning an acknowledgment of the source of used information (citation) is the simplest technique to avoid plagiarism.

questions.statement: Cyberbullying can only happen through email.
questions.explanation: Cyberbullying is an act using the Internet, digital technologies, or mobile phones - not just email.

questions.statement: Cyberbullying can cause developmental issues in children.
questions.explanation: Cyberbullying can be very stressful to the victim, especially children, and can cause several developmental issues.

questions.statement: A white hat hacker breaks into systems for the purpose of fixing flaws and improving security.
questions.explanation: A hacker (white hat hacker) breaks into a computer system for the purpose of fixing flaws and improving security with permission.

questions.statement: A cracker gains unauthorized access to computers to help people.
questions.explanation: A cracker (black hat hacker) gains unauthorized access for the purpose of stealing or corrupting data.

questions.statement: Keyloggers are programs that can read keystrokes to steal confidential information.
questions.explanation: Some programs can read keystrokes pressed by a user on a keyboard to steal confidential information. These are called Keyloggers.

questions.statement: A firewall is used to start fires in computers.
questions.explanation: A firewall is a network security program to keep a check on incoming and outgoing information.

questions.statement: Norton, MacAfee, and Kaspersky are examples of antivirus software.
questions.explanation: Norton, MacAfee, Kaspersky, Quick Heal are examples of antivirus programs mentioned in the textbook.

questions.statement: Phishing emails often promise prizes like lottery winnings to trick users.
questions.explanation: Phishing e-mails often promote gifts and lure users into revealing their private credentials.

questions.statement: Banks will often ask you to send your password by email.
questions.explanation: Banks will NEVER ask you to send your password or personal information by e-mail.

questions.statement: A secured website URL starts with https:// and shows a closed lock icon.
questions.explanation: Enter sensitive data only in secured websites that start with https:// and show a closed lock icon.

questions.statement: Vishing uses phone calls or voice messages to steal information.
questions.explanation: Vishing is a fraudulent act of using phone calls or voice messages pretending to be from a genuine company to steal confidential information.

questions.statement: E-mail bombing is sending requests to a resource many times more than it can handle.
questions.explanation: E-mail bombing is repeatedly sending the same e-mail to a particular address. Flooding is sending requests many times more than resources can handle.

questions.statement: A cookie is a malicious virus that destroys your computer.
questions.explanation: A cookie is a small piece of data that collects information of your online activity and reports it to the host for marketing purposes.

questions.statement: COPPA is a law created to protect the privacy of children under 13 years of age.
questions.explanation: The Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) is a law created to protect the privacy of children under 13 years of age.

questions.statement: Software piracy is legal if you share with friends.
questions.explanation: Software piracy is illegal copying of software without buying the license. You cannot give duplicate copies to your friends.

questions.statement: Copyright laws protect creative works such as books, movies, music, and software.
questions.explanation: Copyright laws typically protect creative works such as books, movies, music, paintings, photographs, and software.

questions.statement: A trademark is used to protect inventions.
questions.explanation: A trademark is used to identify and distinguish products. A patent is used to protect inventions.

questions.statement: A patent gives the creator the sole right to make, use, and sell an invention.
questions.explanation: A patent is a legal right that gives the creator of an invention the sole right to make, use, and sell that invention for a set period.

questions.statement: Cybercrime includes identity theft, forgery, defamation, and credit card account theft.
questions.explanation: Cybercrime includes identity theft, forgery, defamation, mischief, credit card account theft, etc.

questions.statement: Cybercrime is not punishable under any law.
questions.explanation: Cybercrime is punishable under IT Acts enacted in most countries with imprisonment and monetary fine.

questions.statement: Digital footprint is the information about a user that exists on the Internet from their online activity.
questions.explanation: The information about a particular user that exists on the Internet as a result of their online activity is called digital footprint.

questions.statement: Whatever you do online persists and establishes your online identity.
questions.explanation: Whatever you do online persists and establishes your online identity. Digital footprint can make or break your reputation.

questions.statement: A strong password should be at least 8 to 10 characters long.
questions.explanation: The length of the password should be at least 8 to 10 characters for it to be strong.

questions.statement: You should use your name or date of birth as a password because it's easy to remember.
questions.explanation: Do not use your name, family member's name, or date of birth as password, as these are easy to guess.

questions.statement: You should share your password with everyone so they can help you if you forget.
questions.explanation: Avoid writing down your password or sharing it with anyone. Only share with your parents.

questions.statement: You should check the 'Remember Password' option on public computers for convenience.
questions.explanation: Don't check the Remember Password or Stay Signed in option when working on public computers.

questions.statement: Spyware surveys your Internet behavior and copies your passwords without your knowledge.
questions.explanation: The spyware program surveys your Internet behavior and copies your passwords to use them for illegitimate purposes without your knowledge.

questions.statement: You should always download and install software without your parents' permission.
questions.explanation: Before you download and install a software, take permission of your parents.

questions.statement: Social networking sites have no minimum age requirement for membership.
questions.explanation: Many social networking sites prescribe a minimum age limit for membership. Do not acquire membership by faking your age.

questions.statement: Some companies search a candidate's online profile before giving them a job.
questions.explanation: Some companies search the candidate's online profile before giving the job. Similarly, some colleges give admission after searching the applicant's online profile.

questions.statement: Cyberterrorism is using the Internet to carry out violent activities causing loss of life.
questions.explanation: Cyberterrorism is an act of using the Internet to carry out violent activities causing loss of life or intimidation.
